metadata.title: Convert EUR to GBP – Currency Converter
metadata.description: Convert euros to British pounds instantly with ECB/BoE cross guidance, fee modeling, and audit-friendly rate notes.

fields.label: Amount in EUR
fields.helpText: Enter the EUR amount you want to convert; negatives are blocked for clean accounting.

fields.label: EUR → GBP rate
fields.helpText: Auto-fetched from ECB/BoE cross; edit to match your bank’s quote (e.g., 0.86 means €1 = £0.86).

fields.label: Fee or spread (%)
fields.helpText: Optional markup or fee; set to 0 for pure mid-market.

fields.label: Rate date
fields.helpText: Pick a specific date or leave blank for the latest reference rate.

introduction: Convert EUR to GBP in one step with a controllable rate and fee, ideal for invoices, payroll reimbursements, and FX sanity checks.
We anchor guidance to ECB/Bank of England reference data while giving you an explicit fee input to mirror bank or card spreads.
Copy the gross and net pound values to keep quotes and audit trails transparent.
methodology: Multiply EUR by your EUR→GBP rate; use the ECB/BoE cross as a baseline and adjust for your provider’s spread.
An optional fee percent applies a markdown: GBP_after_fee = EUR × rate × (1 – fee/100), reflecting common bank or card costs.
Rates move intraday; record the source and timestamp (e.g., BoE reference, ECB cross, or FRED/IMF series) when logging for compliance or invoicing.
examples: €250 at 0.86 → £215.00 before fees; at a 1% fee it yields £212.85.
€50 travel cash at 0.84 with a 3% ATM fee → £40.74 after fee.

faqs.question: Which rate should I use?
faqs.answer: Use the ECB/BoE reference as a neutral anchor, then adjust the fee field to reflect your bank, broker, or card spread.

faqs.question: How often do rates change?
faqs.answer: Interbank rates move throughout the day. Refresh the rate field from your trusted source and note the time when logging or invoicing.

faqs.question: Why include a fee percent?
faqs.answer: Most providers add a spread. Applying a percent keeps quotes realistic and audit-ready versus pure mid-market figures.

faqs.question: Can I remove the fee?
faqs.answer: Yes. Set the fee to 0 to see the mid-market conversion without spreads.

faqs.question: Is this suitable for compliance records?
faqs.answer: Yes—record the rate source, timestamp, and any applied fee. ECB/BoE reference rates, FRED, or IMF data are standard references.

summary: EUR input with controllable rate and fee delivers both gross and net GBP outputs.
ECB/BoE and Federal Reserve references anchor rate selection; fee control mirrors real-world spreads.
Examples and FAQs emphasize timestamping and source tracking for invoices and compliance.

glossary.definition: Benchmark FX rate published by a trusted authority (e.g., ECB or Bank of England) used as a neutral mid-market anchor.
The markup or markdown applied by providers above the mid-market rate.
